unnormalised: So, exams are over, and the results are finally out! I know, the wait can be killer, right? Especially when you’re constantly refreshing the board’s website, hoping that 90+% pops up next to your name. It’s like waiting for the chaiwala to finally hand you that perfect cup after a long day.
normalised: So, exams are over, and the results are finally out! I know, the wait can be killer, right? Especially when you’re constantly refreshing the board’s website, hoping that ninety plus percent pops up next to your name. It’s like waiting for the chaiwala to finally hand you that perfect cup after a long day.

unnormalised: First off, congrats to everyone who passed! Doesn’t matter if it was 60% or 85%, you made it through. Seriously, give yourselves a pat on the back. Remember all those late-night study sessions fuelled by Maggi and desperation? It paid off. And to those who didn't quite get the results they wanted, bhai, it’s not the end of the world. Life's full of preponed surprises, and sometimes those surprises need a bit of prep time.
normalised: First off, congrats to everyone who passed! Doesn’t matter if it was sixty percent or eighty five percent, you made it through. Seriously, give yourselves a pat on the back. Remember all those late-night study sessions fuelled by Maggi and desperation? It paid off. And to those who didn't quite get the results they wanted, bhai, it’s not the end of the world. Life's full of preponed surprises, and sometimes those surprises need a bit of prep time.

unnormalised: I remember my own Class 10 results. CBSE, the ultimate test of teenage angst! I was aiming for a solid 80%, minimum. My parents, like most Indian parents, had visions of me acing IIT-JEE and becoming an engineer. Talk about pressure!
normalised: I remember my own Class ten results. C-B-S-E, the ultimate test of teenage angst! I was aiming for a solid eighty percent, minimum. My parents, like most Indian parents, had visions of me acing I-I-T-J-E-E and becoming an engineer. Talk about pressure!

unnormalised: The day the results came out, the site crashed, obviously. Millions of us hitting refresh at the same time! Finally, after what felt like an eternity, I saw it: 78%. Not quite the 80 I wanted, but hey, not a disaster either. My maths score was decent, around 82/100, and science was a respectable 75. But English? Oh man, English was my nemesis – a measly 68%.
normalised: The day the results came out, the site crashed, obviously. Millions of us hitting refresh at the same time! Finally, after what felt like an eternity, I saw it: seventy eight percent. Not quite the eighty I wanted, but hey, not a disaster either. My maths score was decent, around eighty two divided by one hundred, and science was a respectable seventy five. But English? Oh man, English was my nemesis – a measly sixty eight percent.

unnormalised: My parents were… well, let's just say there were some disappointed sighs. But my nani, bless her heart, said, "Beta, marks don’t define you. Focus on what you’re good at." That stuck with me.
normalised: My parents were… well, let's just say there were some disappointed sighs. But my nani, bless her heart, said, "Beta, marks don’t define you. Focus on what you’re good at." That stuck with me.

unnormalised: The thing is, those numbers – the percentages, the marks out of 100 – they’re just one snapshot. They don’t show the whole picture. They don’t capture the creativity, the hard work, the late-night study sessions, the pressure we put ourselves under.
normalised: The thing is, those numbers – the percentages, the marks out of one hundred – they’re just one snapshot. They don’t show the whole picture. They don’t capture the creativity, the hard work, the late-night study sessions, the pressure we put ourselves under.

unnormalised: I've seen classmates who scored 98% in everything end up doing jobs they hate. And I've seen those who barely scraped through become incredibly successful entrepreneurs, artists, and activists. Life has a funny way of leveling the playing field, no?
normalised: I've seen classmates who scored ninety eight percent in everything end up doing jobs they hate. And I've seen those who barely scraped through become incredibly successful entrepreneurs, artists, and activists. Life has a funny way of leveling the playing field, no?

unnormalised: So, what’s the takeaway? Celebrate your achievements, learn from your setbacks, and remember that your worth isn't defined by a number. Whether you scored 50% or 99%, it is a stepping stone, not the destination.
normalised: So, what’s the takeaway? Celebrate your achievements, learn from your setbacks, and remember that your worth isn't defined by a number. Whether you scored fifty percent or ninety nine percent, it is a stepping stone, not the destination.

unnormalised: Don’t let anyone tell you otherwise. Go out there, do what you love, and make your own marks on the world. After all, real success is measured not in percentages, but in happiness and fulfillment. And that’s something no exam can ever test. Celebrate with a plate of gulab jamun! You've earned it.
normalised: Don’t let anyone tell you otherwise. Go out there, do what you love, and make your own marks on the world. After all, real success is measured not in percentages, but in happiness and fulfillment. And that’s something no exam can ever test. Celebrate with a plate of gulab jamun! You've earned it.
